title: 107_s798
content: The "Productivity, Opportunity, and Prosperity Act of 2001" includes a new section providing a credit for expenses for remedial education for employees under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Productivity, Opportunity, and Prosperity Act of 2001" introduces a new section that offers a 30% tax credit for qualified remedial education expenditures incurred by employers for their employees. Remedial education includes literacy, numeracy, and English as a second language training. This credit is separate from other existing tax credits. The new section offers a 30% tax credit for remedial education expenses incurred by employers for employees. All persons treated as a single employer under specific sections are considered a single employer for this credit. The credit is now part of the general business credit. The Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection for a Remedial Education Credit, disallowing a deduction equal to the credit amount determined under section 45E(a) for the taxable year. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection for a Remedial Education Credit, disallowing a deduction equal to the credit amount determined under section 45E(a) for the taxable year. The amendments made by this section shall apply to expenses paid or incurred in the taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, there is an Investment Tax Credit for Qualified Information Technology Property. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a Small Business Digital Divide Credit, allowing a 10 percent credit for small business employers in any taxable year. The Small Business Digital Divide Credit offers a 10 percent credit for small business employers based on their basis in qualified information technology property placed in service during the taxable year. Qualified information technology property includes computer technology and equipment. Small business employers are defined as those with an average of 100 or fewer employees during the taxable year. The Small Business Digital Divide Credit provides a 10 percent credit for small business employers based on their basis in qualified information technology property. This credit applies to computer technology and equipment. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified information technology property in the credit basis for small business employers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified information technology property in the credit basis for small business employers. Section 48 is amended to include energy credit, reforestation credit, and small business digital divide credit. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there are increased exclusion and other modifications applicable to qualified small business stock. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock from 50% to 100%. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Code to reflect this change. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock from 50% to 100%. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Code to reflect this change, including redesignating paragraphs and amending headings. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the holding period for gains from certain small business stock from 5 years to 3 years. Additionally, the exclusion for corporations is clarified, stating that stock held among members of a controlled group is not eligible. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the holding period for gains from certain small business stock from 5 years to 3 years. Stock held by a group is not considered qualified small business stock. The minimum tax preference is repealed, and the eligibility threshold for larger businesses is increased to $300,000,000. Inflation adjustment for qualified small business stock under Section 1202(d) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase the $300,000,000 asset limitation by a cost-of-living adjustment for stock issued after 2002. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $10,000, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10,000. The repeal of per-issuer limitations on taxpayer's eligible gain under Section 1202(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is discussed. Additionally, modifications such as extending the working capital period to 5 years and adding a waiver for stock purchases with a business purpose under Section 1202(c)(3) are highlighted. The amendment allows for a waiver of stock purchases by the issuing corporation if there was a business purpose and not to avoid limitations. The effective date for these changes applies to stock issued after the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by subsections (a), (c), (e), (f), and (g)(1) of the Act apply to stock issued after August 10, 1993. SEC. 5 repeals the minimum tax preference for exclusion for incentive stock options. It applies to options exercised in calendar years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6 establishes a 3-year depreciable life for semiconductor manufacturing equipment. SEC. 5 repeals the minimum tax preference for exclusion for incentive stock options. SEC. 6 establishes a 3-year depreciable life for semiconductor manufacturing equipment. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the classification of property and semiconductor manufacturing equipment. Amended by removing items related to subparagraph (B)(ii) and (B)(iii) and adding new provisions. The amendments made by this section apply to equipment placed in service after the enactment of this Act.
